0.text: DAVID CAMERON: Thank you very much, it is great to be here with you tonight, and it's great to

6.text: be with you because we've got 100 to get this man elected as

10.text:
the next Mayor of London. We're here in
the greatest city on earth - London is a

22.text:
great city, it's got a lot greater over
the last eight years with Boris Johnson

26.text: as Mayor - didn't he do a great job! It's a great city because we've seen huge

35.text:
investment coming to London, we've seen
improvement in London schools, we built

39.text:
houses in London and there's been a real
transformation of London's economy.

44.text: Since I've been in your Prime Minister there are half a million more people in work

48.text:
in our capital city - so we've done great
things, we're gonna go on doing great things.

56.text: Here's the truth - great cities need great mayors.Boris  was a great man and I believe

64.text:
that this man Zac Goldsmith can be a
great Mayor too. He has got a very clear

70.text:
vision for what he wants to do for our
city. Zac knows this is a great city for

75.text: all the reasons I've just given, but we've gotta make it a great city for

79.text:
Londoners to live in. Londoners want to
make sure they get a job that pays well.

85.text: Londoners as well make sure they can they can own a home they can afford. Londoners want  a city where it's

90.text: easy and safe to travel around. Londoners want safer streets. That is the agenda

97.text: that this man is all about.

99.text: Let me tell you about this man

106.text: I've sat in Parliament with Zac Goldsmith, and I know what he stands for,  I know who he stands up for. Zac is not a

114.text:
party man, he doesn't do things cause the
party tells him - I know that my cost on

120.text:
occasion! Zac's not in it for the prestige
or the fame or the photo calls. Zac has

127.text: been a member of Parliament for Richmond and he's done an amazing job for people

131.text: in Richmond. Zac stands for the very people he represents - nothing else. And that's what he'll do for London.

147.text: No party posturing, no funny games, no funny business, just simply standing up and delivering for London.

156.text: That is the man we've got in front of us and that's the man who should be the next Mayor of London

166.text: Zac's going to tell you about his plan, but it's vital that we've got the right man, we've got the right plan.

171.text: We built more homes in London but Zac wants to double

174.text: the number of homes in London. We're going to build starter homes, we're gonna build

178.text: shared ownership homes, we're gonna help people save homes - we're gonna get London

182.text: building and we're going to get Londoners owning. That's what we want to do in our capital city.

192.text: Working with Boris, we've done a lot on transport. Crossrail I think is going to be genuinly

197.text:
revolutionary for London, but now we need
the next stages and I want to make sure I

202.text:
work with Zac to deliver the night tube -
that's vital. To make sure we really work

207.text:
on improving those suburban rail
franchises that the mayor's now going to

210.text:
have control on .There's a really big
transport agenda. And you don't need me

214.text:
to tell you that Zac is going to
deliver a green London, that's close to

218.text:
his heart and that's absolutely what he
wants to deliver.

226.text: But I think that here tonight it's also important to talk about the fourth element of that plan,

233.text:
We have to recognise the scale of the terrorist
threat that we face in London. What

239.text:
happened in Paris, that could have
happened here. And I will do everything I

242.text:
can as your Prime Minister to help keep
London and Londoners safe and I know

247.text:
that working with Zac I'll be able to
do just that -  Mayor and a Prime Minister

251.text:
who know we've got to be tough on the
Islamist extremists that want to divide

257.text:
our country. We know we've got to be
tough in terms of providing the extra

261.text:
policemen on our streets, and we know
we're going to be tough in making sure

264.text:
there are sufficient armed police
on London streets so they can respond if

269.text:
they need to in the result of an
incident, and that will always be the

272.text: case when I am your Prime Minister and he's your Mayor.

279.text:
So you've got the the man,
you've got the plan, now just think for a

283.text: moment about the alternative. We've got one man with a record of delivery and we got

292.text: And this is his record. Sadiq Khan, there's one thing you need to know about him - in fact two:

296.text:
1. He nominated Jeremy Corbyn to be
leader of the Labour Party

302.text: 2. He doesn't regret nominating Jeremy Corbyn to be leader. Now this is serious,

306.text: it's serious for Londoners. Nevermind the fact that you know he wants to give the

310.text:
Falklands back to Argentina, or he thinks
that nuclear submarine should patrol the

314.text:
Atlantic without any missiles, or he
wants to twin Britain with Bolivia - actually I made that

318.text:
last one up -  nevermind - you got the sort
of message. Just think

322.text:
about this for the future of London. This
Labour leader, this mayoral candidate.

327.text:
Their policy is to bring back and
legalize secondary strikes and flying

332.text:
pickets. Now I'm not that old, I'm getting
older - but I can remember the industrial

337.text:
chaos, and the strikes in the dislocation
for ordinary hard-working people when we

342.text:
had those things in place, and just think
for a moment what having you know the

347.text:
first Corbyn-elected mayor in
London would be like for our economy, for

353.text:
education, for our politics, for our city.
It would be a disaster. You do not want

358.text:
to be lab rats in the first Corbyn
economics experiment in public life in

363.text:
our country. So we've got to win this, that's
the alternative. It's not a referendum this

368.text:
election, it's a choice. you can have a
Zac as the mayor or you can have

372.text: Jeremy Corbyn's candidate for the Mayor. That is the fight that we've got, and we've got

377.text:
100 days left to win so I say let's
use those hundred days to get out there,

383.text:
door by door, street by street, and tell
people about this man, about his plan.

388.text:
About how working with a Conservative
Prime Minister we can deliver for London;

393.text:
we can deliver the jobs, we can deliver
the homes, we can deliver the better

396.text:
schools, we can deliver the safer streets,
we can deliver the cleaner greener

400.text: London that Zac Goldsmith believes in. I'm gonna give this campaign everything I've got

405.text:
in the next hundred days and I want you
to do as well. Now that's hear it from Zac Goldsmith

430.text: ZAC GOLDSMITH: Hard to follow that, thank you Prime Minister for coming here to support my campaign, and than you all for coming here.

439.text: We have 100 days, 100 days before London makes a choice.

444.text: 100 Days before Boris Johnson steps down as Mayor of London, I think you'll all agree that

450.text: that he has been a fantastic Mayor.

459.text: We've seen record investment, our streets are safer than they have been for decades.

468.text: Record number of jobs, record number of startup businesses on his watch.

473.text: He has put London back on the map, and I have to tell you , I say this a lot

477.text: and every time I say it it reminds me how lucky I am that he isn't a candidate in this election.

485.text: But, I've been to every corner of London as

488.text: part of this campaign, I've spoken to anyone who'll speak to me -  and there's one clear theme,

492.text:
one clear anxiety, one clear concern that
Londoners have. There is a feeling that  whole

498.text:
swaths of Londoners are being priced out
of ttheir own city and they are right. When an average

506.text: Londoner on an average income cannot afford to buy their own home that is a problem.

510.text:
When an average Londoner on a double
the average

517.text: wage  cannot afford their own home, that is a crisis. This is not just a political crisis, it is a

523.text:
social crisis, it's a business crisis and
economic crisis and we need to take it

528.text:
head on. The next mayor and probably the
mayor afterwards is going to have to find a way

532.text:
of taking that extraordinary success
story that is Boris Johnson and turning

537.text:
it into something that matters for all
Londoners. Translating it across the board.

542.text:
Last week I launched this plan which the
Prime Minister has just described - More

547.text: homes, that means closing the gap between what we know Londoners need, and what we

552.text:
currently building. Making London more
affordable to Londoners. Better transport, that

557.text: means growing the networ. The reason we need to grow the network is not just so that

561.text: people can get from one side of London to the other, not just to keep London moving.

566.text:
But because if we grow that network we
unlock the land we're going to need to deal

571.text:
with the housing crisis which is the
number one issue in London.

576.text: Cleaner air - but it's not just air, it's our environment - our living environment.

580.text: We are one of the greenest cities on Earth. We need to protect and cherish our green spaces.

586.text:
We need to protect our green belt but we
also need to tackle the pollution in

590.text:
our air that is taking nearly 10,000 lives
every year prematurely.

595.text:
This has become a big
political issue and of course safer

599.text:
streets. That means protecting the
resources that the police need, it means

603.text:
giving the police our backing, giving
them the tools they need to keep London

608.text: safe.That is what this plan will do. But here's the thing- none of that is possible,

614.text:
none of it, without a mayor who is
capable and willing to work with

618.text:
government, and there's a simple reason
for that.

620.text:
London depends almost completely on
central government for its powers and it's funding.

625.text:
The first line in the job
description of the Mayor of London is

630.text: get a good deal from government, and hold them to account where you need to,

634.text: duff them up if you have to but get a good deal for this city - that is a prerequisite. And

639.text:
my record as an MP over the last
five years, I hope will prove to

644.text:
Londoners that I will do that. I've held
government to account, I'm sure the Prime

649.text:
Minister in the private room would say
that I've been a pain in the backside at

652.text:
times - but I have delivered for my
constituents day-in day-out. And I was

656.text:
rewarded just a few months ago with the
biggest swing in my favor, the biggest

661.text:
increase majority in London one of the
biggest things in my favor in the

666.text: country. A big mandate, a big green light from the people who know me best. As a mayoral

671.text:
candidate just in the last few months I
have also delivered for London.

675.text:
I negotiated with government to knock the
housing bill into shape and as a

680.text:
consequence, and I have to thank other
colleagues in London,  Conservative

683.text: colleagues and the current Mayor of London.

685.text:
As a consequence we have
a bill which guarantees more affordable

689.text: homes for London. I campaigned alongside my colleagues  to have TFL classified as an

695.text:
essential service, and it is an essential
service for almost everyone in London.

700.text: That doesn't mean that there can't be strikes and I'm not going to pretend it does but it does mean that if there are

705.text:
strikes in TFL, that can only happen with
a big democratic mandate. And I fought to

711.text:
protect the police budget. It has been
protected and the consequences that

716.text:
neighbourhood policing will be protected
now  in every single community in London ,and

721.text:
that matters now perhaps more than at
any time in the last two or three

725.text:
decades. Now that compares with the
alternative. A man - Jeremy Corbyn's

731.text:
candidate whose record of delivery
locally as you just heard - he inherited a

737.text:
rock-solid safe Labour seat he turned it
miraculously in just a matter of years

741.text:
into a marginal. Which compares with his
record as a minister - he presided I

748.text:
recently discovered,  he presided over a
period as housing minister as a period

753.text:
of time where fewer houses have been
built since the 1920s.

757.text:
His record is not all that hot but even more
than that, Sadiq Khan cannot deliver for

764.text:
London. And there's a reason for that - he
cannot deliver for London  because he cannot work with people

769.text:
outside his own political party. His
entire approach to politics is partisan.

774.text:
He will not attempt to build bridges to
people in different parties , he certainly

778.text:
won't engage with the government, the
same government incidentally that will

783.text:
be in charge effectively of London over
the next four years.

789.text: Sadiq Khan is an architect in this madness we've seen in the Labour Party over the last few months. If he

797.text:
wins in May, we will have years and
years of infighting, the same infighting

804.text:
that has characterised the Labour Party
over the last few months.

807.text: We'll see London for four years treated as a testing ground, a laboratory for Corbyn's

813.text: radical politics. And that is the price we cannot pay. Now London is, we all agree the

820.text:
greatest city on Earth. But we are at a
turning point, a decision time awaits

826.text: London. Now I have a plan; more homes, better transport, cleaner air, safer streets.

832.text: But that that cannot be delivered by a mayor

834.text:
who will not engage with government. We
have just 100 days to go until

840.text:
London makes its decision, and the
choice could not be clearer. It's Corbyn's man in

846.text: city hall, or your man in city hall.

860.text: I know, that London can be made even greater still.

865.text: I know that, you know that. And I know that with your help

869.text: I will absolutely promise you that it will.

872.text: So, a big thank you to all of you who have come here today,

876.text: thank you for all the help you have already given me, I depend on you completely

879.text: to help get me over the line in May, so please join me for the next 100 days,

882.text: we will give this everything we have, thank you.
